qas.question: How many regional dialects does Czech have?
Where are dialects of Czech commonly found?
What is dialect use associated with and thus stigmatized because of?
What kind of scholarly interest has Czech received?
What Czech dialect is gaining ground in journalism and the mass media?
What class was being a journalist associated with?

plausible_answers.text: literature or other media for comedic effect

qas.question: What were parodies of journalists used for?
What has increased among politicians and business people since 1990 so they are more well known locally?

plausible_answers.text: During the second half of the twentieth century

qas.question: When did interest in studying ancient texts start to weaken?
What group became more prominent in the 1990's when people wanted to hear the news of the day?

context: In addition to a spoken standard and a closely related written standard, Czech has <a0_0>several<a0_0/> regional dialects primarily used in <a1_0>rural areas<a1_0/> by speakers less proficient in other dialects or standard Czech. <b8_0>During the second half of the twentieth century<b8_0/>, Czech dialect use began to weaken. By the early 1990s dialect use was stigmatized, associated with the shrinking <a2_0><b5_0>lower class<b5_0/><a2_0/> and used in <b6_0>literature or other media for comedic effect<b6_0/>. <b7_0>Increased travel and media availability<b7_0/> to dialect-speaking populations has encouraged them to shift to (or add to their own dialect) standard Czech. Although Czech has received <a3_0>considerable<a3_0/> scholarly interest for a Slavic language, this interest has focused primarily on modern standard Czech and ancient texts rather than dialects. Standard Czech is still the norm for politicians, businesspeople and other Czechs in formal situations, but <a4_0>Common<a4_0/> Czech is gaining ground in journalism and the <b9_0>mass media<b9_0/>.
